anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
how many games in a row have the uconn women's basketball team won
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
["UConn is well-known for its men's and women's basketball teams, both of which are considered among the best programs in the country. The men's basketball teams have won four National Championships (1999, 2004, 2011 and 2014) while the women's basketball teams have won eleven National Championships (1995, 2000, 2002, 2003, 2004, 2009, 2010, 2013, 2014, 2015 and 2016) and have played in a total of 19 NCAA Final Fours, including nine in a row. The women's team went undefeated in the 1995, 2002, 2009, 2010, 2014 and 2016 seasons and ended a 111-game winning streak in the 2017 NCAA Division I Women's Basketball Tournament.\n", "The Connecticut Huskies are the team of the University of Connecticut (UConn); they play NCAA Division I sports. Both the men's basketball and women's basketball teams have won multiple national championships. In 2004, UConn became the first school in NCAA Division I history to have its men's and women's basketball programs win the national title in the same year; they repeated the feat in 2014 and are still the only school to win both titles in the same year. The UConn women's basketball team holds the record for the longest consecutive winning streak in NCAA college basketball at 111 games, a streak that ended in 2017. The UConn Huskies football team has played in the Football Bowl Subdivision since 2002, and has played in four bowl games.\n", "UConn women entered the 2010–11 season ranked No.\xa01 in all the national polls. On December 19, 2010, the UConn Huskies beat No.\xa010 ranked Ohio State at Madison Square Garden's annual Maggie Dixon Classic to tie the NCAA consecutive win streak to 88 games, and on December 21, 2010 they beat No.\xa020 ranked Florida State at the XL Center in Hartford to set a new NCAA consecutive win record at 89 games, the streak ended at 90 on December 30, 2010 with a 71–59 loss at Stanford.\n", "The team has been especially successful on its home court in the Harry A. Gampel Pavilion on the UConn campus in Storrs, Connecticut, and in the larger XL Center in Hartford; they tied an NCAA women's basketball record with 69 consecutive home wins between 2000 and 2003. That record was broken in 2011. The last home loss was to Villanova in the game that ended their 70-game winning streak. Moreover, between Auriemma's arrival and the close of the 2005 season, UConn won 295 games versus just 31 losses. The team set Big East Conference records for both single-game and season-long attendance.\n", "Women's basketball was not a major sport at UConn until the arrival of Auriemma in 1985. Under his guidance UConn has enjoyed unprecedented success, winning 11 national titles, including six at the end of undefeated seasons and four consecutive championships from 2013–16. The Huskies also have the two longest winning streaks in NCAA Division I basketball history, at 111 games from 2014–17 and 90 games from 2008–10. Connecticut's rivalry with women's basketball power Tennessee has been one of the most celebrated in the sport. Twenty-six former UConn women's basketball players have gone on to play in the Women's National Basketball Association (WNBA), and five—Sue Bird in 2002, Diana Taurasi in 2004, Tina Charles in 2010, Maya Moore in 2011, and Breanna Stewart in 2016—have been selected first overall in the WNBA Draft. Stewart, Moriah Jefferson, and Morgan Tuck were the first three picks in the 2016 draft; this marked the first time three players from the same college were selected 1-2-3 in the draft of any major sport.\n"]

2. **Winning Streaks**:
   - The passages mention two significant winning streaks: a 111-game winning streak that lasted from 2014 to 2017 and a 90-game winning streak from 2008 to 2010.
   - The 111-game streak is noted as the longest consecutive winning streak in NCAA college basketball history, which emphasizes its historical importance.
   - The mention of these streaks provides a quantitative measure of the team's success and highlights their dominance in women's college basketball.

3. **Specific Game Records**:
   - The passages detail specific instances of the UConn women's team breaking records, such as tying the NCAA consecutive win streak at 88 games and setting a new record at 89 games in December 2010.
   - This information illustrates the progression of their winning streaks and the competitive nature of their achievements.

4. **Impact of Coaching**:
   - The arrival of coach Geno Auriemma in 1985 is highlighted as a turning point for the program, leading to unprecedented success.
   - Understanding the role of coaching provides insight into the factors contributing to the team's winning streaks and overall performance.

5. **Rivalries and Cultural Significance**:

### Analysis of the Role of These Contents:

- **Establishing Context**: The historical achievements and records set by the UConn women's basketball team provide a backdrop that enhances the understanding of their winning streaks. It positions the team within a broader narrative of excellence in women's sports.

- **Cultural Significance**: The references to rivalries and the impact of the team's success on women's basketball culture highlight the broader implications of their achievements, making it clear that their winning streaks are not just statistical milestones but also part of a larger story in sports history.

To enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities, we can extract and consolidate relevant information from the provided passages about the UConn women's basketball team. Here’s a summary of the key points:

1. **Historical Success**: The UConn women's basketball team has won eleven National Championships and has played in a total of 19 NCAA Final Fours. This establishes a context of sustained excellence and dominance in women's college basketball.

2. **Winning Streaks**: The team holds the record for the longest consecutive winning streak in NCAA college basketball at 111 games, which lasted from 2014 to 2017. Additionally, they had a previous streak of 90 games from 2008 to 2010. These statistics highlight the team's ability to maintain high performance over extended periods.

3. **Undefeated Seasons**: UConn's women's team went undefeated in several seasons (1995, 2002, 2009, 2010, 2014, and 2016), indicating not only skill but also consistency in performance across multiple years.

4. **Significant Milestones**: The team set a new NCAA consecutive win record at 89 games in December 2010, which emphasizes their ability to surpass previous benchmarks and achieve new heights in performance.

5. **Home Court Dominance**: UConn has been particularly successful at home, tying an NCAA women's basketball record with 69 consecutive home wins between 2000 and 2003, and breaking that record in 2011. This suggests a strong home-court advantage and the importance of fan support in their success.

### Analysis of Impact on Causal Reasoning and Logical Inference

4. **Benchmarking Success**: The records set by the UConn women's team serve as benchmarks that the model can use to evaluate other teams' performances. This comparative analysis can enhance logical reasoning by allowing the model to assess relative success and infer potential outcomes based on established standards.

5. **Causal Inference**: By analyzing the reasons behind the team's success (e.g., coaching strategies, player development), the model can improve its causal inference capabilities, allowing it to draw more nuanced conclusions about what leads to success in sports or other competitive environments.

In summary, the extracted information provides a rich context for understanding the UConn women's basketball team's success, which can significantly enhance the model's causal reasoning and logical inference abilities by allowing it to recognize patterns, understand temporal relationships, consider contextual factors, benchmark success, and make causal inferences.

The UConn women's basketball team holds the record for the longest consecutive winning streak in NCAA college basketball at 111 games, a streak that ended in 2017. Gampel Pavilion on the UConn campus in Storrs, Connecticut, and in the larger XL Center in Hartford; they tied an NCAA women's basketball record with 69 consecutive home wins between 2000 and 2003. Connecticut's rivalry with women's basketball power Tennessee has been one of the most celebrated in the sport. question_info.question: how many games in a row have the uconn women's basketball team won
passages:
UConn is well-known for its men's and women's basketball teams, both of which are considered among the best programs in the country. The men's basketball teams have won four National Championships (1999, 2004, 2011 and 2014) while the women's basketball teams have won eleven National Championships (1995, 2000, 2002, 2003, 2004, 2009, 2010, 2013, 2014, 2015 and 2016) and have played in a total of 19 NCAA Final Fours, including nine in a row. The women's team went undefeated in the 1995, 2002, 2009, 2010, 2014 and 2016 seasons and ended a 111-game winning streak in the 2017 NCAA Division I Women's Basketball Tournament.
The Connecticut Huskies are the team of the University of Connecticut (UConn); they play NCAA Division I sports. Both the men's basketball and women's basketball teams have won multiple national championships. In 2004, UConn became the first school in NCAA Division I history to have its men's and women's basketball programs win the national title in the same year; they repeated the feat in 2014 and are still the only school to win both titles in the same year. The UConn women's basketball team holds the record for the longest consecutive winning streak in NCAA college basketball at 111 games, a streak that ended in 2017. The UConn Huskies football team has played in the Football Bowl Subdivision since 2002, and has played in four bowl games.
UConn women entered the 2010–11 season ranked No. 1 in all the national polls. On December 19, 2010, the UConn Huskies beat No. 10 ranked Ohio State at Madison Square Garden's annual Maggie Dixon Classic to tie the NCAA consecutive win streak to 88 games, and on December 21, 2010 they beat No. 20 ranked Florida State at the XL Center in Hartford to set a new NCAA consecutive win record at 89 games, the streak ended at 90 on December 30, 2010 with a 71–59 loss at Stanford.
The team has been especially successful on its home court in the Harry A. Gampel Pavilion on the UConn campus in Storrs, Connecticut, and in the larger XL Center in Hartford; they tied an NCAA women's basketball record with 69 consecutive home wins between 2000 and 2003. That record was broken in 2011. The last home loss was to Villanova in the game that ended their 70-game winning streak. Moreover, between Auriemma's arrival and the close of the 2005 season, UConn won 295 games versus just 31 losses. The team set Big East Conference records for both single-game and season-long attendance.
Women's basketball was not a major sport at UConn until the arrival of Auriemma in 1985. Under his guidance UConn has enjoyed unprecedented success, winning 11 national titles, including six at the end of undefeated seasons and four consecutive championships from 2013–16. The Huskies also have the two longest winning streaks in NCAA Division I basketball history, at 111 games from 2014–17 and 90 games from 2008–10. Connecticut's rivalry with women's basketball power Tennessee has been one of the most celebrated in the sport. Twenty-six former UConn women's basketball players have gone on to play in the Women's National Basketball Association (WNBA), and five—Sue Bird in 2002, Diana Taurasi in 2004, Tina Charles in 2010, Maya Moore in 2011, and Breanna Stewart in 2016—have been selected first overall in the WNBA Draft. Stewart, Moriah Jefferson, and Morgan Tuck were the first three picks in the 2016 draft; this marked the first time three players from the same college were selected 1-2-3 in the draft of any major sport.
